skill.name: nmap
skill.description: Professional network reconnaissance and port scanning using nmap. Supports various scan types (quick, full, UDP, stealth), service detection, vulnerability scanning, and NSE scripts. Use when you need to enumerate network services, detect versions, or perform network reconnaissance.
skill.summary: Professional network reconnaissance and port scanning using nmap. Supports various scan types (quick, full, UDP, stealth), service detection, vulnerability scanning, and NSE scripts.
skill.author: BrownFineSecurity

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate network reconnaissance skill for authorized security testing. The static analyzer flagged network scanning patterns because this skill IS designed for port scanning. All nmap commands are legitimate tool usage with hardcoded templates, not command injection risks. The skill explicitly requires authorization and documents ethical usage guidelines. Risk is inherent to security reconnaissance tools but appropriate for the marketplace.

content.value_statement: Security professionals need to enumerate network services and identify vulnerabilities. This skill automates professional nmap port scanning with multiple scan types, service detection, and NSE scripts for comprehensive network reconnaissance.
actual_capabilities: Execute fast port discovery scans with SYN stealth scanning
Perform service version detection with -sV flag
Run Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE) scripts for vulnerability detection
Scan UDP ports and perform OS fingerprinting
Parse and analyze nmap output files
Support multiple scan types including quick, full, stealth, and aggressive scans
limitations: Requires nmap to be installed on the system
Some scan types require root or sudo privileges
UDP scans are significantly slower than TCP scans
Cannot scan targets without network access

use_cases.title: Authorized security assessment
use_cases.description: Perform comprehensive network reconnaissance during authorized penetration testing engagements. Use two-phase scanning strategy for efficient port discovery and service enumeration.

use_cases.title: IoT device discovery
use_cases.description: Identify IoT devices and their exposed services. Run targeted scripts for RTSP, MQTT, UPnP, and ONVIF protocols commonly found in smart devices.

use_cases.title: Network inventory and auditing
use_cases.description: Map network infrastructure and document running services. Generate reports of open ports, service versions, and potential security issues.
use_cases.target_user: Network administrators and IT security auditors

prompt_templates.title: Quick port scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a quick nmap scan on [TARGET_IP] to discover open ports and services. Use service detection and save output to ./nmap-output directory.
prompt_templates.scenario: Initial reconnaissance on a single target

prompt_templates.title: Full network scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a comprehensive nmap scan on network [NETWORK_CIDR] scanning all 65535 ports. Run service detection and vulnerability scripts on discovered services.
prompt_templates.scenario: Complete network assessment requiring full port coverage

prompt_templates.title: Stealth reconnaissance
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a stealth SYN scan on [TARGET] to avoid detection. Use slow timing template and save results for later analysis.
prompt_templates.scenario: Red team engagement requiring evasion techniques

prompt_templates.title: IoT device enumeration
prompt_templates.prompt: Scan [TARGET_IP] for IoT-specific services. Run scripts for RTSP, HTTP methods, and common IoT protocols. Focus on ports 80, 443, 554, 1883, and 8000.

output: Phase 1: Fast SYN scan on all 65535 ports
Phase 2: Service detection on open ports

output_examples.input: Scan network range for IoT devices

best_practices: Always save nmap output using -oA flag to generate normal, XML, and grepable formats
Use the two-phase strategy: fast port discovery followed by targeted service detection
Verify you have explicit authorization before scanning any target
anti_patterns: Running scans without saving output or documenting results
Using aggressive timing on production systems without understanding impact
Scanning targets without verifying authorization scope

faq.question: Does this skill require nmap to be installed?
faq.answer: Yes, nmap must be installed on the system. The skill provides command templates but relies on the nmap binary being available.

faq.question: Why does the skill use sudo for some scans?
faq.answer: Certain nmap features require root privileges: SYN stealth scans (-sS), UDP scans (-sU), OS detection (-O), and raw packet operations. The skill documents when sudo is required.

faq.question: Can I scan any target with this skill?
faq.answer: You should only scan targets you have explicit authorization to test. Unauthorized scanning may be illegal and violates ethical guidelines.

faq.question: How long do scans typically take?
faq.answer: Fast port discovery takes 1-3 minutes. Service detection on open ports adds 1-3 minutes. UDP scans are much slower and may take 10+ minutes for top 100 ports.

faq.question: What output formats are generated?
faq.answer: Using -oA flag generates three formats: .nmap (human-readable), .xml (machine-readable), and .gnmap (grep-able) for parsing with scripts.

faq.question: Can this skill detect vulnerabilities?
faq.answer: Yes, using --script vuln runs NSE vulnerability detection scripts. However, this is basic scanning; comprehensive vulnerability assessment requires dedicated tools.
